s.text: In some strains, cells with [PSI + ] prion demonstrated better survival than their non-prion counterparts in the presence of inhibitors of translation or microtubules, heavy metals, low pH, and other deleterious conditions, which of course gives a strong advantage to the [PSI + ] cells.
Many damaged and mutant polypeptides, as well as some normal proteins, have a tendency to aggregate in cells.
The abnormal aggregated species can recruit normal soluble PrP molecules into aggregates, thus inactivating them.
In fact, in the absence of Hsp104, prion aggregates continue to grow without increase in number and are rapidly lost in generations (Wegrzyn et al.

Certain yeast prion proteins, when in soluble conformation, function in important pathways; e.g., Sup35 (forming [PSI + ] prion) controls termination of translation, and Ure2 (forming [URE3 + ] prion) controls some membrane transporter systems.
This work, therefore, clarifies the architecture of prions by defining two structural motifs in prion proteins that have distinct functions in aggregation and propagation.
These domains are often found in transcription factors, protein kinases, and components of vesicular transport.
The common structural feature of yeast prion proteins is the so-called prion domain, characterized by the high content of glutamines (Q) and asparagines (N) (DePace et al.
[PSI + ] could also reveal previously silent mutations or their combinations.
In fact, in the absence of Hsp104, prion aggregates continue to grow without increase in number and are rapidly lost in generations (Wegrzyn et al.
